qas.question: What is another name for "Curia Regis"?
Who was it that peculiarly called a full parliament without royal authorization in 1265?
As a result, the bishops, abbots, earls, and barons formed which body of parliament?
Which body did the shire and borough representatives form?
What positions were contained within the House of Lords?
Which branch of parliament contains shire and borough representatives?
A bill could not become a law without whose assent?
Who is considered the enactor of laws?

plausible_answers.text: bishops, abbots, earls, barons, and two knights from each shire and two burgesses

qas.question: In 1665, the Earl of Leicester called a full parliament without what?
The Queen would seek the advice of whom before making laws?
The two houses in England are the House of Luck and?

plausible_answers.text: originate legislation in the form of bills

qas.question: During Henry VIII's reign, it became common for the two houses to do what?

context: Originally, legislative power was exercised by the sovereign acting on the advice of the <a4_0>Curia Regis, or <a0_0>Royal Council<a4_0/><a0_0/>, in which important magnates and clerics participated and which evolved into parliament. The so-called Model Parliament included <b9_0>bishops, abbots, earls, barons, and two knights from each shire and two burgesses<b9_0/> from each borough among its members. In 1265, the <a1_0>Earl of Leicester<a1_0/> irregularly called a full parliament without <b10_0>royal authorisation<b10_0/>. The body eventually came to be divided into two branches: <a5_0>bishops, abbots, earls, and barons<a5_0/> formed the <a2_0>House of Lords<a2_0/>, while the shire and borough representatives formed <b12_0>the <a3_0><a6_0>House of Commons<b12_0/><a6_0/><a3_0/>. The King would seek the advice and consent of <b11_0>both houses<b11_0/> before making any law. During Henry VI's reign, it became regular practice for the two houses to <b13_0>originate legislation in the form of bills<b13_0/>, which would not become law unless <a7_0>the sovereign<a7_0/>'s assent was obtained, as <a8_0>the sovereign<a8_0/> was, and still remains, the enactor of laws. Hence, all acts include the clause "Be it enacted by the Queen's (King's) most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows...". The Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949 provide a second potential preamble if the House of Lords were to be excluded from the process.
